TopicTitle: A day on starship, an essay.

Articles.Content:
This is a short, (hopefully non-terrible) essay I made, based on my imagination of a day on the SpaceX starship on the way to Mars, this version of the starship is my version of a starship crew ship mark 2, all the hardcore astronauts have all gone to Mars, and to make it more appealing, they cut the crew capability in half, allowing for more cabin space, and made an escape pod, to escape a failed launch. the cabins are pretty much identical to space news pod's design, and the rest of the ship is explained during the essay. I imagined it from the point of me if I were on the starship.  Anyways, I hope you don't think it's horrible  : 

 

Log entry: 2042-01-29:

As usual I woke up a couple of minutes before my alarm could go, I pulled one hand out of my sleeping bag and checked my phone, 05:57, it said, I unlocked it and turned my alarm off before it went. I unzipped my bag and, still half asleep, drifted towards the roof with Leeutjie (my teddy lion I've had for as long as I can remember, his name means small lion in Afrikaans) under my arm. I blearily took my toothbrush from it's velcro attachment and brushed my teeth, before putting my phone, Swiss army knife, and packet of duct-tape in my pockets, then I silently opened my cabin's sliding door and coasted towards the center (vertical) hallway. I grabbed a handle-bar at the top and swang around so that I was travelling feet first, towards the cafeteria, when I arrived I swang myself inwards and navigated to the stockpile (where all the food is). The rest of the crew would be waking up at 06:30, I have to wake up earlier so that I can be in the caf before they arrive, (I'm a robotics engineer and I will really only have a job to do once on Mars, so they assigned me to bar-tender duty while on the way). I took some sausages, some mango, and some droëwors (a popular South African snack, we could pick some of our own food to bring with us, so I made a version which doesn't make a mess in 0g), and began eating.

I was halfway through my mango, when Cap (our nickname for our commander) came in and asked for breakfast, after getting her breakfast she left and went to check on the equipment, taking her breakfast with her. I was almost finished with my mango when the rest of the crew's alarms went off in the 2 hab floors below me. I gave them breakfast while taking a bite of my own food every chance I got. After they were finished I ate the last of my sausages, and kept the droëwors in case I needed a snack, after that I had to restock the stockpile, so I went to the "tip" (our constantly pressurized cargo bay which would also work as a launch escape pod, it has high-g chairs for all 50 of us, all our personal cargo, which we have now moved into our cabins (we had a max of 10kg each of personal items) and our food supply), I once I arrived, I let Leeutjie float (sidenote: he was our 0g indicator on launch) and pulled out the next month's food container, before grabbing Leeutjie and coasting back down with the container, past the observatory/"rec" and into the caf. It would take a while to pack it all out and sort it, so I asked for help on "ship-net" (the ship's personal network, we can message each other, look things up, watch movies, tv, or read books on it and avoid long transmission times with it) and Luis, (one of the other guys who also has almost no job on the way to Mars), came to help. 

We finished around 09:30. After that I went to the bathroom, shaved, went to my cabin, and watched an episode of MythBusters (Rest In Peace Grant Imahara). Then, around 11:00 I had to go to one of our two daily gym sessions, I mostly jogged on the tredmill. I finished just before twelve o'clock and went to my cabin, where I relaxed, continued re-reading the Hitch-hiker's guide to the galaxy, and played some KSP-2 on my laptop. At 1 pm, we had lunch, and it was basically the same ordeal as breakfast, after that a couple of us played a game I came up with, Zero-g drone racing, in the "rec", I'd built a small drone, fitted it with a massive battery, and made a course, I coded it to pilot it in 0g. It is a lot of fun, although I usually lose. After that I went down to the lab (situated below the lowest hab floor but above the main unpressurized (the whole thing will act as an airlock on Mars) cargo bay), to help one of the other engineers to get the 0g 3d printer up and running again. After that I spent a while in my cabin relaxing, competing in a race around the Ovin eleven (Ovin, it's rings, it's moons, and a couple of stations we made around it) in KSP-2, I came second out of the 5 of us who raced. after that I finished re-reading Hitchhiker's, went to gym session 2 and did practically the same as lunch when we had dinner.

After dinner, our data-dump came through and Jo-Ann, our sysop showed us the news, nothing much, just a new rocketlab Graviton launch, a small status update from the martian colony, and a couple of other things on Earth. After that I read some Asterix (a very funny French comic) and updated this log, anyways, it's almost bedtime, Good night.

 

I hope you thought it was ok, I had a lot of fun writing it.  

By the way: Yes, I really am South African, and yes, I do sleep with a teddy lion named Leeutjie (pronounced Lee-oo-ki) and no I am not ashamed
